p.s: The speech from Sir David Attenborough held at COP26 opening sa people's advocate on the first of November of 2021 deals with the current issue: climate change.
At the beginning at his speech, he reminds the audience of the urgency of climate change.
He then continues by pointing out the history of humans in regards to the earth.
He states that when the number of people stabilized, the earth's climate did too and as a result seasons and the weather were predictable and reliable.
According to Attenborough, there has been a natural balance at this time, which has been destroyed due to human activity.
Furthermore, Sir David Attenborough talks about how developing countries are most affected by climate change, although they have done the least to cause the problem.
As a result, he calls for action to stop the rising number of global warming.
He argues that the government at the COP26 conference alreaady have the knowledge to start a revolution with sustainable innovations.
Moreover, Mr. Attenborough says that all countries are in the same boat and therefore have to work together.
At the end of his speech, he gives the audience hope by saying that the rise of global warming could stop.
In his speech, Sir David Attenborough appeals to the audience by using all inclusive language and by underlining the urgency of climate change.
He starts his speech with a direct adressaddress to the audience: Your excellencies, delegates, ladies and gentlemen (l. 11).
Furthermore, he mentions the history of humans and the earth.
Over 10.000 years ago [the] number [of people living on the earth] [...] stabilized and with it, Earth's climate(ll. 9-10).
Therefore, the global temperature has not wavered [...] by more than plus or minus one degree Celsius (ll. 13-14).
He then calls for action by [restoring] the wild, it will recapture carbon and help us bring back balance to our planet (ll. 35-36).
In addition, he states that no nation has completed its development because no advanced nation is yet sustainable (ll. 37-38), which makes it clear to the audience that they are all in the same boat.
Sir David Attenborough argues that there is hope to believe tht the answer [to question, if the global temperature will stop rising] can be yes (ll. 49-50).
